csharp_simple:
1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Double Exponential Moving Average (DEMA)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// A faster moving average that reduces lag by using a combination of single and double EMAs.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>Formula: DEMA = 2 * EMA(P) - EMA(EMA(P))</description></item>
13 /// </list>
14 /// </remarks>
15 public class DoubleExponentialMovingAverage
16 {
17 public int Period { get; }
18 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
19​
20 public DoubleExponentialMovingAverage(int period)
21 {
22 Period = period;
23 }
24​
25 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
26 {
27 Values.Clear();
28 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
29​
30 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
31​
32 // Step 1: EMA of Price
33 var ema1 = CalculateEma(candleList, Period);
34
35 // Step 2: EMA of EMA1
36 var ema2 = CalculateEmaFromValues(ema1, Period);
37​
38 // Step 3: DEMA Formula
39 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
40 {
41 if (i < ema1.Count && i < ema2.Count && ema1[i].HasValue && ema2[i].HasValue)
42 Values.Add(2 * ema1[i]!.Value - ema2[i]!.Value);
43 else
44 Values.Add(null);
45 }
46 }
47​
48 private static List<decimal?> CalculateEma(List<CandleData> candles, int period)
49 {
50 var results = new List<decimal?>();
51 if (candles.Count == 0 || period <= 0) return results;
52​
53 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
54 decimal? prevEma = null;
55​
56 for (int i = 0; i < candles.Count; i++)
57 {
58 if (i < period - 1)
59 {
60 results.Add(null);
61 continue;
62 }
63​
64 if (i == period - 1)
65 {
66 decimal sum = 0;
67 for (int j = 0; j < period; j++)
68 sum += candles[i - j].Close;
69 prevEma = sum / period;
70 results.Add(prevEma);
71 continue;
72 }
73​
74 if (prevEma != null)
75 {
76 decimal ema = (candles[i].Close - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
77 results.Add(ema);
78 prevEma = ema;
79 }
80 else
81 {
82 results.Add(null);
83 }
84 }
85 return results;
86 }
87​
88 private static List<decimal?> CalculateEmaFromValues(List<decimal?> source, int period)
89 {
90 var results = new List<decimal?>();
91 if (source.Count == 0 || period <= 0) return results;
92​
93 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
94 decimal? prevEma = null;
95 int validCount = 0;
96​
97 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
98 {
99 if (!source[i].HasValue)
100 {
101 results.Add(null);
102 continue;
103 }
104​
105 validCount++;
106​
107 if (validCount < period)
108 {
109 results.Add(null);
110 continue;
111 }
112​
113 if (validCount == period)
114 {
115 decimal sum = 0;
116 int count = 0;
117 for (int j = i; j >= 0 && count < period; j--)
118 {
119 if (source[j].HasValue)
120 {
121 sum += source[j]!.Value;
122 count++;
123 }
124 }
125 prevEma = count > 0 ? sum / count : null;
126 results.Add(prevEma);
127 continue;
128 }
129​
130 if (prevEma.HasValue)
131 {
132 decimal ema = (source[i]!.Value - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
133 results.Add(ema);
134 prevEma = ema;
135 }
136 else
137 {
138 results.Add(null);
139 }
140 }
141 return results;
142 }
143​
144 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period)
145 {
146 var dema = new DoubleExponentialMovingAverage(period);
147 dema.Calculate(candles);
148 return dema.Values;
149 }
150 }
151}
csharp_detailed:
1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (DoubleExponentialMovingAverage)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Double Exponential Moving Average (DEMA) technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. Exponential Moving Average (EMA)
13// [Why] Weights recent data more heavily to react faster than SMA.
14// [How] EMA = (Price - PrevEMA) * k + PrevEMA
15//
16// 2. The Lag Problem
17// [Why] All Moving Averages lag behind price. By the time they turn, the move might be over.
18// [What] Patrick Mulloy (1994) created DEMA to reduce this lag significantly.
19//
20// 3. Double EMA Formula
21// [Why] Not just "EMA of EMA". It uses a clever subtraction to cancel out lag.
22// [How]
23// EMA1 = EMA(Price) -> Lag level 1
24// EMA2 = EMA(EMA1) -> Lag level 2 (smoother, but more lag)
25// DEMA = 2*EMA1 - EMA2 -> Adds the difference back to boost responsiveness.
26//
27// [Visual Plan]
28// Step 1: Calculate single EMA of prices (EMA1).
29// Step 2: Calculate EMA of the EMA1 series (EMA2).
30// Step 3: Combine them using the formula.
31//
32// =============================================================================
33​
34using System;
35using System.Collections.Generic;
36​
37namespace TechnicalIndicators
38{
39 // =============================================================================
40 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
41 // =============================================================================
42 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
43​
44 // =============================================================================
45 // Logic Explanation: Double Exponential Moving Average Class
46 // =============================================================================
47 public class DoubleExponentialMovingAverage
48 {
49 // -------------------------------------------------------------
50 // Logic Explanation: Configuration
51 // -------------------------------------------------------------
52 public int Period { get; }
53 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
54​
55 // =============================================================================
56 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
57 // =============================================================================
58 public DoubleExponentialMovingAverage(int period)
59 {
60 if (period <= 0)
61 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
62 Period = period;
63 }
64​
65 // =============================================================================
66 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
67 //
68 // [Why] Orchestrates the three-step process: EMA1 -> EMA2 -> DEMA.
69 // =============================================================================
70 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
71 {
72 // -------------------------------------------------------------
73 // Step 1: Cleanup
74 // -------------------------------------------------------------
75 Values.Clear();
76 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
77​
78 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
79​
80 // -------------------------------------------------------------
81 // Step 2: Compute Components (EMA1 and EMA2)
82 //
83 // [Why] (Intent)
84 // We need the intermediate series to apply the final formula.
85 //
86 // [Note]
87 // - CalculateEma: Works on CandleData list.
88 // - CalculateEmaFromValues: Works on decimal? list (output of EMA1).
89 // -------------------------------------------------------------
90 var ema1 = CalculateEma(candleList, Period);
91 var ema2 = CalculateEmaFromValues(ema1, Period);
92​
93 // -------------------------------------------------------------
94 // Step 3: Compute DEMA
95 //
96 // [Formula] DEMA = 2 * EMA1 - EMA2
97 //
98 // [Visual]
99 // Index: 0 ... 10 ... 20
100 // EMA1: - 100 105
101 // EMA2: - - 102
102 // DEMA: - - 2*105 - 102 = 108
103 // -------------------------------------------------------------
104 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
105 {
106 // Ensure both components exist at this index
107 if (i < ema1.Count && i < ema2.Count && ema1[i].HasValue && ema2[i].HasValue)
108 {
109 Values.Add(2 * ema1[i]!.Value - ema2[i]!.Value);
110 }
111 else
112 {
113 Values.Add(null);
114 }
115 }
116 }
117​
118 // =============================================================================
119 // Logic Explanation: Helper - Standard EMA on Candles
120 // =============================================================================
121 private static List<decimal?> CalculateEma(List<CandleData> candles, int period)
122 {
123 var results = new List<decimal?>();
124 if (candles.Count == 0 || period <= 0) return results;
125​
126 // Multiplier k = 2 / (N + 1)
127 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
128 decimal? prevEma = null;
129​
130 for (int i = 0; i < candles.Count; i++)
131 {
132 // -------------------------------------------------------------
133 // Phase A: Insufficient Data
134 // -------------------------------------------------------------
135 if (i < period - 1)
136 {
137 results.Add(null);
138 continue;
139 }
140​
141 // -------------------------------------------------------------
142 // Phase B: Bootstrap (First Valid Point)
143 //
144 // [Why] EMA is recursive; it needs a starting point.
145 // Standard convention is to use SMA of the first 'Period' bars.
146 // -------------------------------------------------------------
147 if (i == period - 1)
148 {
149 decimal sum = 0;
150 for (int j = 0; j < period; j++)
151 sum += candles[i - j].Close;
152
153 prevEma = sum / period;
154 results.Add(prevEma);
155 continue;
156 }
157​
158 // -------------------------------------------------------------
159 // Phase C: Recursive Calculation
160 //
161 // [Formula] EMA = (Price - Prev) * k + Prev
162 // -------------------------------------------------------------
163 if (prevEma != null)
164 {
165 decimal ema = (candles[i].Close - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
166 results.Add(ema);
167 prevEma = ema;
168 }
169 else
170 {
171 // Should not happen if logic flows correctly from Phase B
172 results.Add(null);
173 }
174 }
175 return results;
176 }
177​
178 // =============================================================================
179 // Logic Explanation: Helper - EMA on Existing Values (Chained EMA)
180 //
181 // [Why] EMA2 is calculated on top of EMA1 values, not CandleData.
182 // EMA1 contains nulls at the start, which we must handle.
183 // =============================================================================
184 private static List<decimal?> CalculateEmaFromValues(List<decimal?> source, int period)
185 {
186 var results = new List<decimal?>();
187 if (source.Count == 0 || period <= 0) return results;
188​
189 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
190 decimal? prevEma = null;
191 int validCount = 0;
192​
193 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
194 {
195 // -------------------------------------------------------------
196 // Step A: Skip Null Inputs
197 //
198 // [Why] EMA1 has leading nulls. EMA2 calculation must wait
199 // until valid EMA1 numbers appear.
200 // -------------------------------------------------------------
201 if (!source[i].HasValue)
202 {
203 results.Add(null);
204 continue;
205 }
206​
207 // We found a valid number
208 validCount++;
209​
210 // -------------------------------------------------------------
211 // Step B: Wait for Period Length of Valid Data
212 //
213 // [Why] Like Phase A above, we need N valid points before starting.
214 // -------------------------------------------------------------
215 if (validCount < period)
216 {
217 results.Add(null);
218 continue;
219 }
220​
221 // -------------------------------------------------------------
222 // Step C: Bootstrap (SMA of EMA1 values)
223 // -------------------------------------------------------------
224 if (validCount == period)
225 {
226 decimal sum = 0;
227 int count = 0;
228
229 // Look back through source to find the valid values we just counted
230 for (int j = i; j >= 0 && count < period; j--)
231 {
232 if (source[j].HasValue)
233 {
234 sum += source[j]!.Value;
235 count++;
236 }
237 }
238
239 prevEma = count > 0 ? sum / count : null;
240 results.Add(prevEma);
241 continue;
242 }
243​
244 // -------------------------------------------------------------
245 // Step D: Recursive Calculation
246 // -------------------------------------------------------------
247 if (prevEma.HasValue)
248 {
249 decimal ema = (source[i]!.Value - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
250 results.Add(ema);
251 prevEma = ema;
252 }
253 else
254 {
255 results.Add(null);
256 }
257 }
258 return results;
259 }
260​
261 // =============================================================================
262 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
263 // =============================================================================
264 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period)
265 {
266 var dema = new DoubleExponentialMovingAverage(period);
267 dema.Calculate(candles);
268 return dema.Values;
269 }
270 }
271}
python_simple:
1class DoubleExponentialMovingAverage:
2 """
3 Double Exponential Moving Average (DEMA)
4 2 * EMA - EMA(EMA)
5 """
6 def __init__(self, period=10):
7 self.period = period
8 self.values = []
9​
10 def calculate(self, candles):
11 self.values.clear()
12 if len(candles) == 0: return
13​
14 # 1. EMA 1
15 ema1 = self._calculate_ema(candles, self.period)
16
17 # 2. EMA 2 (EMA of EMA1)
18 ema2 = self._calculate_ema_from_values(ema1, self.period)
19
20 # 3. DEMA
21 for i in range(len(candles)):
22 if i < len(ema1) and i < len(ema2) and ema1[i] is not None and ema2[i] is not None:
23 self.values.append(2 * ema1[i] - ema2[i])
24 else:
25 self.values.append(None)
26
27 def _calculate_ema(self, candles, period):
28 results = []
29 if len(candles) == 0: return results
30
31 k = 2.0 / (period + 1)
32 prev_ema = None
33
34 for i in range(len(candles)):
35 if i < period - 1:
36 results.append(None)
37 continue
38
39 if i == period - 1:
40 s = sum(c['close'] for c in candles[i-period+1:i+1])
41 prev_ema = s / period
42 results.append(prev_ema)
43 continue
44
45 if prev_ema is not None:
46 ema = (candles[i]['close'] - prev_ema) * k + prev_ema
47 results.append(ema)
48 prev_ema = ema
49 else:
50 results.append(None)
51 return results
52​
53 def _calculate_ema_from_values(self, source, period):
54 results = []
55 k = 2.0 / (period + 1)
56 prev_ema = None
57 valid_count = 0
58
59 for i in range(len(source)):
60 if source[i] is None:
61 results.append(None)
62 continue
63
64 valid_count += 1
65 if valid_count < period:
66 results.append(None)
67 continue
68
69 if valid_count == period:
70 # Sum of last N valid values
71 # Looking back is tricky with Nones in between, but here Nones are only at start.
72 # So we can just take slice of valid ones?
73 # Implementation detail: just sum backwards.
74 s = 0.0
75 c = 0
76 for j in range(i, -1, -1):
77 if source[j] is not None:
78 s += source[j]
79 c += 1
80 if c == period: break
81 prev_ema = s / c
82 results.append(prev_ema)
83 continue
84
85 if prev_ema is not None:
86 ema = (source[i] - prev_ema) * k + prev_ema
87 results.append(ema)
88 prev_ema = ema
89 else:
90 results.append(None)
91 return results
92​
93def calculate(candles, period=10):
94 dema = DoubleExponentialMovingAverage(period)
95 dema.calculate(candles)
96 return dema.values
python_detailed:
1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (DoubleExponentialMovingAverage - DEMA)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Double Exponential Moving Average (DEMA). We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Lag Reduction
11# Standard EMA has lag. DEMA attempts to remove this lag by subtracting the
12# "error" of the EMA (which is EMA(EMA)).
13#
14# 2. The Formula
15# DEMA = 2 * EMA(n) - EMA(EMA(n))
16# NOT simply a "double smoothing". It uses the double-smoothed value to
17# CORRECT the single-smoothed value.
18#
19# 3. Responsiveness
20# DEMA reacts much faster than SMA or EMA to price changes.
21#
22# =============================================================================
23​
24​
25# -------------------------------------------------------------
26# Type-Level Explanation: DoubleExponentialMovingAverage (class)
27#
28# [Why] Complex calculation requiring multiple passes (EMA, EMA of EMA).
29# [What] High-performance moving average logic.
30# [How] Uses two parallel EMA calculations (EMA of price, and EMA of that EMA) to subtract the lag from the original EMA.
31# [Who] Algorithmic traders needing fast signals.
32# [Where] Heap allocation.
33# -------------------------------------------------------------
34class DoubleExponentialMovingAverage:
35​
36 # -------------------------------------------------------------
37 # Constructor: __init__
38 #
39 # [Why] Validate period.
40 # [What] Stores lookback period.
41 # -------------------------------------------------------------
42 def __init__(self, period):
43 # -------------------------------------------------------------
44 # Logic Step 1: Validation
45 # -------------------------------------------------------------
46 if period <= 0:
47 raise ValueError("period")
48 self.period = period
49 self.values = []
50​
51​
52 # =============================================================================
53 # IPO: calculate
54 # =============================================================================
55 #
56 # [Input]
57 # - candles: list[dict]
58 #
59 # [Process]
60 # 1. Calc EMA1 (EMA of Price).
61 # 2. Calc EMA2 (EMA of EMA1).
62 # 3. Compute DEMA = 2*EMA1 - EMA2.
63 #
64 # [Output]
65 # - None (populates self.values).
66 # =============================================================================
67 def calculate(self, candles):
68
69 # -------------------------------------------------------------
70 # Logic Step 1: Reset & Guard
71 # -------------------------------------------------------------
72 self.values.clear()
73 if len(candles) == 0:
74 return
75​
76 # -------------------------------------------------------------
77 # Logic Step 2: Calculate Components
78 #
79 # [Why] (Intent)
80 # Low-level signal processing requires 2 passes.
81 # Pass 1: Smoothed price.
82 # Pass 2: Smoothed "trend" of the price.
83 # -------------------------------------------------------------
84 ema1 = self._calc_ema(candles, self.period)
85 ema2 = self._calc_ema_from_values(ema1, self.period)
86​
87 # -------------------------------------------------------------
88 # Logic Step 3: Combine to DEMA
89 #
90 # [Formula] 2*EMA1 - EMA2
91 #
92 # [Visual]
93 # P=100
94 # EMA1 = 98 (Lagging below price)
95 # EMA2 = 97 (Lagging below EMA1)
96 # DEMA = 2*98 - 97 = 196 - 97 = 99
97 # Result: 99 is closer to 100 than 98. Lag reduced!
98 # -------------------------------------------------------------
99 for i in range(len(candles)):
100
101 # -------------------------------------------------------------
102 # Logic Step 3.1: Data Alignment Check
103 #
104 # [Decision]
105 # Do we have valid data for both components?
106 #
107 # [True Branch: Valid Data]
108 # Calculate DEMA.
109 #
110 # [False Branch: Invalid Data]
111 # Append None.
112 # -------------------------------------------------------------
113 if (i < len(ema1) and i < len(ema2) and
114 ema1[i] is not None and ema2[i] is not None):
115
116 dema = 2 * ema1[i] - ema2[i]
117 self.values.append(dema)
118 else:
119 self.values.append(None)
120​
121​
122 # =============================================================================
123 # IPO: _calc_ema (Helper)
124 # =============================================================================
125 #
126 # [Input]
127 # - candles: list[dict]
128 # - period: int
129 #
130 # [Process]
131 # - Standard EMA calculation on Close price.
132 #
133 # [Output]
134 # - list[float|None]
135 # =============================================================================
136 def _calc_ema(self, candles, period):
137 results = []
138 if len(candles) == 0 or period <= 0:
139 return results
140
141 # EMA Multiplier K = 2 / (N + 1)
142 k = 2.0 / (period + 1)
143 prev_ema = None
144​
145 for i in range(len(candles)):
146 # -------------------------------------------------------------
147 # Logic Step 1: Wait for period
148 #
149 # [Decision]
150 # Has the lookback window been filled?
151 #
152 # [True Branch: Insufficient History]
153 # Append None and continue.
154 #
155 # [False Branch: Sufficient History]
156 # Proceed to calculation.
157 # -------------------------------------------------------------
158 if i < period - 1:
159 results.append(None)
160 continue
161
162 # -------------------------------------------------------------
163 # Logic Step 2: First value is SMA (Seed)
164 # -------------------------------------------------------------
165 if i == period - 1:
166 s = sum(candles[i - j]['close'] for j in range(period))
167 prev_ema = s / period
168 results.append(prev_ema)
169 continue
170
171 # -------------------------------------------------------------
172 # Logic Step 3: Recursive EMA
173 # New = (Price - Prev) * K + Prev
174 # -------------------------------------------------------------
175 if prev_ema is not None:
176 ema = (candles[i]['close'] - prev_ema) * k + prev_ema
177 results.append(ema)
178 prev_ema = ema
179 else:
180 results.append(None)
181
182 return results
183​
184​
185 # =============================================================================
186 # IPO: _calc_ema_from_values (Helper)
187 # =============================================================================
188 #
189 # [Input]
190 # - source: list[float|None] (This is EMA1!)
191 # - period: int
192 #
193 # [Process]
194 # - EMA calculation on an already computed array.
195 # - CRITICAL: Must skip 'None' values in the source.
196 #
197 # [Output]
198 # - list[float|None]
199 # =============================================================================
200 def _calc_ema_from_values(self, source, period):
201 results = []
202 if len(source) == 0 or period <= 0:
203 return results
204
205 k = 2.0 / (period + 1)
206 prev_ema = None
207 valid_count = 0
208​
209 for i in range(len(source)):
210 # -------------------------------------------------------------
211 # Logic Step 1: Skip Initial Gaps
212 #
213 # [Why] (Intent)
214 # EMA1 has Nones at the start. EMA2 (EMA of EMA1) starts calculating
215 # only after EMA1 is valid.
216 # -------------------------------------------------------------
217 if source[i] is None:
218 results.append(None)
219 continue
220
221 valid_count += 1
222
223 # -------------------------------------------------------------
224 # Logic Step 2: Wait for secondary period
225 # -------------------------------------------------------------
226 if valid_count < period:
227 results.append(None)
228 continue
229
230 # -------------------------------------------------------------
231 # Logic Step 3: Seed (SMA of EMA1)
232 # -------------------------------------------------------------
233 if valid_count == period:
234 s = 0
235 count = 0
236 j = i
237 # Look back only at valid numbers
238 while j >= 0 and count < period:
239 if source[j] is not None:
240 s += source[j]
241 count += 1
242 j -= 1
243
244 prev_ema = s / count if count > 0 else None
245 results.append(prev_ema)
246 continue
247
248 # -------------------------------------------------------------
249 # Logic Step 4: Recursive EMA2
250 # -------------------------------------------------------------
251 if prev_ema is not None:
252 ema = (source[i] - prev_ema) * k + prev_ema
253 results.append(ema)
254 prev_ema = ema
255 else:
256 results.append(None)
257
258 return results
259​
260​
261# =============================================================================
262# Static Wrapper Function
263# =============================================================================
264#
265# [Why]
266# Functional interface.
267#
268# [Pattern: 3-Step Static Wrapper]
269# =============================================================================
270def calculate(candles, period):
271 # 1. Instantiation
272 dema = DoubleExponentialMovingAverage(period)
273
274 # 2. Execution
275 dema.calculate(candles)
276
277 # 3. Extraction
278 return dema.values
